<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of BASE64Encode:
```c
static ssize_t
BASE64Encode (const void *in, size_t len, char **output)
{
#define FILLCHAR '='
  const char *cvt = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ"
                    "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz"
                    "0123456789+/";
  const char *data = in;
  char *opt;
  ssize_t ret;
  size_t i;
  char c;
  ret = 0;

  opt = malloc (2 + (len * 4 / 3) + 8);
  if (NULL == opt)
  {
    return -1;
  }
  for (i = 0; i < len; ++i)
  {
    c = (data[i] >> 2) & 0x3F;
    opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    c = (data[i] << 4) & 0x3F;
    if (++i < len)
    {
      c = (char) (c | ((data[i] >> 4) & 0x0F));
    }
    opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    if (i < len)
    {
      c = (char) (c | ((data[i] << 2) & 0x3F));
      if (++i < len)
      {
        c = (char) (c | ((data[i] >> 6) & 0x03));
      }
      opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    }
    else
    {
      ++i;
      opt[ret++] = FILLCHAR;
    }
    if (i < len)
    {
      c = data[i] & 0x3F;
      opt[ret++] = cvt[(int) c];
    }
    else
    {
      opt[ret++] = FILLCHAR;
    }
  }
  *output = opt;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only for-loop in this function is the one starting with 'for (i = 0; i < len; ++i)'. The suspicious fragments listed above cover the loop header and all in-loop modifications of the loop counter (the ++i occurrences and the ++i; in the else branch). Those are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 because they show the loop counter being modified both in the loop header and inside the loop body, and multiple increments of the same counter inside the body. Other parts of the function do not need investigation for Rule 14.2: declarations (const char *cvt, const char *data, char *opt, ssize_t ret, size_t i, char c), the malloc and NULL check, assignments to ret and opt elements, use of cvt and FILLCHAR, casts, and the final *output = opt; return ret; do not affect whether the for-loop is well-formed under Rule 14.2. Also, the object 'len' is never modified in the loop body, so its use in the loop condition does not by itself violate the rule. Therefore only the loop header and the in-body modifications of i need further investigation.
